Saratoga.bias_notes: Deep, tiring track ('Graveyard of Champions'). Rail is often dead/deep in sprints. Favors Stalkers/Closers more than typical dirt tracks. Inner Turf is tight/speed favoring; Outer Turf is fair.

Del Mar.bias_notes: Short stretch (919 ft). Inside posts (1-3) dominant in routes. Speed/Pressers favored on dirt. Turf is narrow and firm.

Gulfstream Park.bias_notes: THE SPEED TRACK. 6F sprints are Wire-to-Wire dominated. Golden Rail is common. One-turn mile plays like a sprint. Turf turns are extremely tight (The Parking Lot) - wide trips are death.

Santa Anita.bias_notes: Speed favoring dirt, but turns to Closer/Stalker bias on wet/sealed tracks (Dead Rail inversion). Hillside Turf (6.5F) favors Closers; Flat Turf is fair.

Keeneland.bias_notes: Short stretch (1/16th pole finish). Fair dirt track but inside speed holds in routes. Turf is wide and sweeping - excellent for Closers. Wesley Ward 2YOs dominate April sprints.

Churchill Downs.bias_notes: Cuppy surface (breaks away). Horse-for-Course is critical. One-turn mile favors speed/cutbacks. Turf trending toward speed.

Aqueduct.bias_notes: Winter Inner Track (Legacy/Main): Dead Rail is common Jan-Mar; Outside flow is better. Sprints favor outside pressers. Inner Turf tight; Outer Turf fair.

Belmont Park.bias_notes: Big Sandy. Massive 1.5m oval. Sweeping turns allow Closers to maintain momentum. One-turn routes favor outside flow. Fairest turf in America.

Tampa Bay Downs.bias_notes: Dirt is sandy/cuppy. Rail can be dead. Turf course is gritty and rewards stamina.

Oaklawn Park.bias_notes: Short stretch. Speed favoring but often has a 'Golden Rail' path in the slop.

Flemington.bias_notes: Long 1200m straight (The Straight Six). Wide tracks often favored. Swoopers paradise on the circle.

Randwick.bias_notes: Fair track but 'The Rise' in the straight tests stamina. Can favor leaders when rail is out 6m+.

Rosehill.bias_notes: Tight turns. Leaders/On-pace runners historically favored. Hard to make ground from back.

Moonee Valley.bias_notes: The 'Saucer'. Extremely tight turns. Short straight (173m). Leader bias is huge.

Caulfield.bias_notes: Tight turns but long-ish straight. Can be leaderish if rail is true.

Ascot.bias_notes: Stiff uphill finish. Stamina is key. High numbers are often drawn wide on the straight course.

Newmarket.bias_notes: The Rowley Mile has a 'Dip' before the finish that unbalances horses. Experience helps.

York.bias_notes: The 'Knavesmire'. Flat, wide, fair galloping track. Speed holds well.

Tokyo.bias_notes: Massive sweeping turns and a long uphill straight. Closers paradise.

Nakayama.bias_notes: Tight turns, short straight with a steep hill. Positional speed is critical.

Kyoto.bias_notes: Flat and fast. The 'descent' into the straight helps momentum runners.

Hanshin.bias_notes: Similar to Nakayama but wider. Power course.
